newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Belgian shares to stop for breath, no big fall.
newsitem.headline: Belgian shares to stop for breath, no big fall.

text.p: Further consolidation is expected for Belgian shares after Wednesday's profit-taking, but dealers see no big downturn.

"New York is down again in early trade today. If it stays there, we should be slightly negative tomorrow," said a trader. "People need a breather and there will be further consolidation, but no dramatic downturn."

In line with weaker neighbouring bourses, the Bel-20 index of leading shares .BFX closed on Wednesday 13.40 points or 0.73 percent down at the day's low of 1,810.15 points. A moderate 1.9 billion Belgian francs worth of shares changed hands.

"We've been more resistant than other European markets lately and today's regression was gentler than elsewhere," said a dealer. "The market's well supported at these levels, though there's not a lot of volume."

Retailer Delhaize was among the biggest losers, shedding 2.7 percent to 1,815 francs on a softer U.S. dollar. Chemicals group Solvay and oil stock Petrofina were also hit, slipping 1.3 and 0.6 percent respectively.
Belgium's biggest bank Generale Bank bucked the trend, gaining 0.7 percent at 10,875 francs, and posted the biggest volume by value, as it bounced back from recent lows.

D'Ieteren surged 3.8 percent to end at 5,710 francs after hitting a record high of 5,950 francs. The car importer and distributor, which is not continuously quoted on the Brussels bourse, was the seventh biggest traded stock by volume, a feat described by traders as "impressive".

"Recent media reports confirmed the company's good earnings trend and business is good at its car hire subsidiary," said a trader. D'Ieteren imports Volkswagen, Audi, Seat, Skoda and Porsche cars, and owns a majority stake in car hire firm, Avis Europe.
